docs.snippet: Reporters for The New York Times spoke with people across the country to understand the issues that split voters before the election, and today....
docs.lead_paragraph: Reporters for The New York Times spoke with people across the country to understand the issues that split voters before the election, and today.
docs.abstract: New York Times reporters offer views of six American voters, representing both Republican- and Democratic- leaning states, as they contemplate potentially divided American future under Donald J Trump presidency.

headline.main: Red, Blue and Divided: Six Views of America
headline.print_headline: Red, Blue and Divided: Six Views of America After Trump’s Win

docs.snippet: The president-elect said his immigration priority was to deport up to three million undocumented immigrants rather than 11 million and that his border wall might be a fence in places....
docs.lead_paragraph: The president-elect said his immigration priority was to deport up to three million undocumented immigrants rather than 11 million and that his border wall might be a fence in places.
docs.abstract: Pres-elect Donald J Trump eases back on some of his hardest-line positions on immigration but reaffirms his intent to roll back abortion rights, taking to Twitter to lash out at critics; Trump's newly-energized social media salvo, unparalleled in history of presidential communication, hints of plans to carry confrontational style of speaking to Americans with him to White House, in effort to blunt impact of news organizations that do not openly affirm his views.

headline.main: Donald Trump Appears to Soften Stance on Immigration, but Not on Abortion
headline.print_headline: On Immigrants and Abortion, and on Twitter

docs.snippet: Rudolph W. Giuliani said it would be ‘unrealistic’ for Mr. Trump to remove his children from his business empire. Ethics experts said the remarks were misguided....
docs.lead_paragraph: Rudolph W. Giuliani said it would be ‘unrealistic’ for Mr. Trump to remove his children from his business empire. Ethics experts said the remarks were misguided.
docs.abstract: Rudolph W Giuliani vice chairman of Donald J Trump's transition team, says it is unrealistic for president-elect to place his business assets in strict blind trust as presidents in past have done; ethics experts disagree, asserting decisions made by new president will be unfairly attacked for conflict of interest unless he follows lead of predecessors.

headline.main: Donald Trump Shouldn’t ‘Put His Children Out of Work,’ Giuliani Says
headline.print_headline: Blind Trust, a Presidential Norm, Is ‘Unrealistic’ for Trump, Giuliani Says

byline.original: By NICHOLAS FANDOS and ERIC LIPTON

docs.lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald Trump on Sunday picked Reince Priebus, a Washington insider who heads the Republican National Committee, as White House chief of staff, signaling a willingness to work with Congress to advance his agenda when he takes office in January.
